verses.text: When King Hezekiah heard this, he tore his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth, and went into the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Hezekiah responds to crisis by seeking God's presence in humility. The act of entering the temple under duress foreshadows seeking God through the sacramental life, especially in times of trial.

verses.text: He sent Eliakim, who was over the household, Shebna the scribe, and the elders of the priests, covered with sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz.
verses.comment: Hezekiah appeals to the prophet, showing the importance of spiritual guidance and hierarchy in times of crisis (cf. Esther 4:16).

verses.text: They said to him, 'This is what Hezekiah says: Today is a day of distress, rebuke, and disgrace, as when children come to the birth, and there is no strength to deliver them.'
verses.comment: A sense of hopelessness points to humanity’s need for divine intervention, anticipating Christ’s role as deliverer (Matthew 1:21).

verses.text: Perhaps the LORD your God will hear the words of the field commander, whom his master, the king of Assyria, has sent to mock the living God, and will rebuke the words that the LORD your God has heard. Therefore, lift up your prayer for the remnant that is left.'
verses.comment: The idea of God defending His honor shows His active involvement with His people, a theme seen in the defense of Christ's divinity in the Gospels (John 10:36), and the value of intercessory prayer.

verses.text: When King Hezekiah's servants came to Isaiah,
verses.comment: Approaching the prophet is a model of seeking authority within the true faith—God's guidance is mediated through chosen leaders (Acts 8:14-17).

verses.text: Isaiah said to them, 'Tell your master, the LORD says: Do not be afraid of the words you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed me.
verses.comment: Fear not—God himself addresses blasphemy. The theme of God’s sovereignty over nations recurs throughout Christ’s teachings and the apostles’ boldness (Acts 4:29-31).

verses.text: Look, I will put a spirit in him so that he will hear a rumor and return to his own land; and I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land.'
verses.comment: God determines the fate of rulers. This prefigures Christ’s ultimate victory over all enemies—not by human strength, but divine will.

verses.text: The field commander returned and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah, for he had heard that he had left Lachish.
verses.comment: God’s providence is seen in large-scale events beyond human planning, fulfilling His promises to protect His chosen people.

verses.text: Now the king heard concerning Tirhakah, king of Cush, 'He has come out to fight against you.' When he heard it, he sent messengers again to Hezekiah, saying,
verses.comment: Assyrian threats persist, even as events unfold elsewhere. Perseverance in faith amidst repeated trials is a key biblical theme.

verses.text: "Say this to Hezekiah, king of Judah: 'Do not let your God, in whom you trust, deceive you by saying, "Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria."'
verses.comment: Pagan powers question the reliability of God—an ancient scheme, echoed when Jesus’ authority was questioned (Matt. 27:43).

verses.text: You have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all lands, by utterly destroying them. Will you then be delivered?
verses.comment: The arrogance of earthly rulers who presume to control God's people. This tension recurs in Daniel and the New Testament when Christians face persecution.

verses.text: Have the gods of the nations that my fathers destroyed delivered them—Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden who were in Telassar?
verses.comment: Pagan gods are no match for the LORD. Only the living God acts in history, as Christ’s resurrection demonstrates decisively (1 Cor. 15:17).

verses.text: Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharvaim, of Hena, and Ivvah?'
verses.comment: The mocking litany echoes challenges made to Christ’s authority, which He answers with divine power and humility.

verses.text: Hezekiah received the letter from the messengers and read it; then Hezekiah went up to the house of the LORD and spread it before the LORD.
verses.comment: This physical gesture of presenting the letter mirrors the concept of offering up one’s burdens to God, an act encouraged in the life of the Church (1 Peter 5:7).

verses.text: Hezekiah prayed to the LORD, saying:
verses.comment: Hezekiah’s prayer is a model of trust and dependence on God—a type of the perfect prayer Christ would later offer (Luke 22:41-44).

verses.text: 'O LORD of hosts, God of Israel, enthroned above the cherubim, you alone are God over all the kingdoms of the earth; you made heaven and earth.'
verses.comment: Affirming God’s uniqueness over creation anticipates Christ’s affirmation, 'I and the Father are one' (John 10:30).

verses.text: 'Incline your ear, O LORD, and hear; open your eyes, O LORD, and see; hear all the words of Sennacherib, which he has sent to mock the living God.'
verses.comment: God is asked to 'see' and 'hear,' echoing themes of God’s accessibility and responsiveness in worship.

verses.text: 'Truly, O LORD, the kings of Assyria have laid waste all the nations and their lands,'
verses.comment: A realistic acknowledgment of worldly power, preparing for an act of divine intervention and reversal.

verses.text: 'and have thrown their gods into the fire, for they were not gods but only the work of men's hands, wood and stone, and so they destroyed them.'
verses.comment: A rejection of idolatry. Places trust in the one true living God, a theme fulfilling itself in Christ's teaching (cf. John 4:24).

verses.text: 'And now, O LORD our God, save us from his hand, so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you, O LORD, are God alone.'
verses.comment: Hezekiah’s prayer is concerned with God’s glory and universal recognition—a foreshadowing of Christ’s mission and the Church’s universality.

verses.text: Then Isaiah, son of Amoz, sent word to Hezekiah: 'Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel: Because you have prayed to me about Sennacherib king of Assyria,
verses.comment: God’s response is prompted by prayer—a lesson in the efficacy and necessity of intercessory prayer in spiritual life.

verses.text: this is the word the LORD has spoken against him: 'The virgin daughter of Zion despises you and mocks you; the daughter of Jerusalem shakes her head behind you.'
verses.comment: ‘Virgin daughter of Zion’ signals God’s protection over His people and has spiritual fulfillment in the purity and faithfulness of the true Church (cf. 2 Cor. 11:2).

verses.text: 'Whom have you mocked and reviled? Against whom have you raised your voice and lifted your eyes proudly? Against the Holy One of Israel!'
verses.comment: God’s own holiness is at stake; offense against God is more serious than a human affront—echoed in the reverence Christ claims for Himself.

verses.text: 'By your servants you have mocked the Lord. You have said, "With my many chariots I have gone up to the heights of the mountains, to the farthest recesses of Lebanon, and I have cut down its tallest cedars, its choicest cypresses, and entered its farthest height, its most fruitful forest."'
verses.comment: Human boasting in power is ultimately futile; divine authority supersedes political or military might.

verses.text: 'I dug wells and drank foreign waters, and with the soles of my feet I dried up all the streams of Egypt.'
verses.comment: The boasting about earthly accomplishments sharply contrasts with God’s creative power. God’s people are called to humility.

verses.text: 'Have you not heard? Long ago I determined it; in days gone by I planned it. Now I have brought it to pass, that you should turn fortified cities into heaps of ruins.'
verses.comment: God’s providence is at work even through pagan rulers, ultimately serving His plan—a sign of His sovereignty.

verses.text: 'Therefore their inhabitants were of little power; they were dismayed and confounded; they were like plants of the field, like green grass, like grass on rooftops, scorched before it is grown.'
verses.comment: Human strength flourishes then fades; true stability is found only in depending on God.

verses.text: 'But I know your sitting down, your going out and your coming in, and your raging against me.'
verses.comment: God’s omniscience is declared—He knows all hearts and motives, a truth brought out even more fully in Jesus’ teaching (John 2:24-25).

verses.text: 'Because you have raged against me and your arrogance has come to my ears, I will put my hook in your nose and my bit in your mouth, and I will turn you back by the way you came.'
verses.comment: God’s judgment reverses arrogance. The strong symbolism signifies divine authority even over the greatest rulers.

verses.text: 'This will be the sign for you: This year you will eat what grows of itself, and the second year what springs from that; and in the third year sow and reap, plant vineyards and eat their fruit.'
verses.comment: A miraculous sign involving agricultural cycles points to God’s providence—including His provision for the faithful through both natural and extraordinary means.

verses.text: 'And the surviving remnant of the house of Judah will again take root below and bear fruit above.'
verses.comment: The faithful remnant persists—foreshadowing Jesus’ emphasis on abiding in Him to bear fruit (John 15:4-5).

verses.text: 'For out of Jerusalem will go forth a remnant, and out of Mount Zion those who escape. The zeal of the LORD of hosts will accomplish this.'
verses.comment: God’s zeal, not human initiative, saves the remnant—a truth fulfilled in Christ’s redeeming work and the preservation of apostolic faith.

verses.text: Therefore this is what the LORD says about the king of Assyria: 'He will not enter this city, shoot an arrow there, come before it with shield, or build a siege ramp against it.'
verses.comment: A promise of total protection—God’s deliverance is complete and miraculously prevents the enemy’s attack.

verses.text: 'By the way that he came, by the same he will return, and he will not enter this city,' says the LORD.
verses.comment: God alone determines the outcome of history, reaffirming His role as protector and savior of His people.

verses.text: 'For I will defend this city and save it, for my own sake and for the sake of my servant David.'
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness to David is a foreshadowing of the Messiah’s lineage and the promises fulfilled in Him. The enduring promise points to the permanence of the true Church.

verses.text: Then the angel of the LORD went out and struck down a hundred and eighty-five thousand in the camp of the Assyrians. When people arose early in the morning, behold, all these were dead bodies.
verses.comment: Divine intervention comes through God’s messenger (angel), showing His power to save even miraculously—anticipating the role of angels in Christ’s ministry (Luke 22:43).

verses.text: So Sennacherib king of Assyria departed and returned home, and lived at Nineveh.
verses.comment: The enemy retreats in defeat—God’s vindication is complete and public.

verses.text: One day, while he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer struck him down with the sword and escaped to the land of Ararat. Then Esarhaddon his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: Sennacherib’s fall, even as he worships his idol, demonstrates the impotence of false gods. The judgment aligns with the principle that only God gives life and removes rulers in His time. The continuity of succession in the narrative also foreshadows the importance of rightful succession in spiritual leadership.
